explanation:
Explain why each symbol is required

- sysconf: This external function is invoked in the compiled code paths. To conclude the target function has no offending for-loops you must know whether sysconf itself contains or invokes any for-loops that would be considered part of a for-loop body when called from this function (MISRA counts called-function behaviour when that call appears inside a for). Although there is no for in the target, determining compiled code may require knowing sysconf semantics and whether it introduces loop behaviour relevant to MISRA checks.

- _SC_CRAY_NCPU and _SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF: These constant macros select which sysconf queries are made. They affect which calls to sysconf are compiled in; knowing their presence/values is needed to determine the exact compiled code and therefore whether any for-loop constructs are present in that compilation.

- HAVE_SYSCONF, HAS_DECL__SC_CRAY_NCPU, HAS_DECL__SC_NPROCESSORS_CONF: These configuration macros control compilation of the sysconf-related block. The MISRA for-loop analysis depends on which blocks are enabled; these macros determine whether the sysconf calls (and thus any potential external loop behaviour) are part of the target function's compiled body. Knowing their definitions (defined/undefined) is required to decide if any additional symbols or called functions need inspection.

Note: No local for-loop constructs appear in the provided source. The listed symbols are the only external/configuration symbols that can change the compiled body of the function and therefore are sufficient to determine whether any for-loop related MISRA violations could arise from this function or from functions it invokes.
